awd_titl_txt: CSR:Small:System Support for Edge Computing Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Edge computing promises to enable many applications not readily supported by the cloud computing paradigm. By placing resource-rich nodes in close proximity to mobile or Internet of Things (IoT) devices, edge computing offers better responsive services, along with higher scalability and availability than traditional cloud platforms. Edge computing, as a new computing paradigm, also poses vastly different research challenges due to its distinct infrastructure from other systems. In this project, a number of novel technologies will be developed to run various applications on an edge computing system with less deployment effort and higher efficiency. 

Specifically, the project proposes a comprehensive architecture for edge computing application development and identifies task scheduling, service migration, data management as enabling techniques for edge computing to prevail. The project will focus on new algorithms and system design methodologies in (1) a task queue management and inter-edge collaboration system, (2) a highly efficient and robust service migration support based on Docker/Virtual Machine, and (3) a combined edge/cloud computing architecture for distributed data management. With respect to broader impacts, this project will advance the state of the art in emerging edge computing systems by designing system support to facilitate the development of a wide variety of edge computing applications, thereby having a positive impact on our daily lives. The new paradigm derived from the research will lead to a number of interesting problems that are not explored in traditional cloud or mobile systems. The findings of this research will be incorporated into new and existing undergraduate and graduate courses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Edge computing is an emerging paradigm that involves deploying computing and storage resources closer to the data source. It facilitates real-time data processing at greater speeds and volumes. This technology has gained substantial momentum across various industries due to its potential to revolutionize data processing, improve decision-making, and foster the creation of new applications. It is envisioned that numerous edge computing applications will be developed, spanning diverse domains such as autonomous vehicles, smart cities, healthcare, and more.

To facilitate the development of edge computing applications, addressing fundamental challenges within the field is crucial. This project endeavors to create robust systems support for edge computing applications, focusing on resolving key research challenges. The objective is to elevate the foundational infrastructure for application developers by addressing critical research issues that constitute essential building blocks in the realm of edge computing.

This project identifies three core research challenges in edge computing: (1) Task scheduling among edge devices, edge servers, and cloud servers. (2) Service migration among edge servers. (3) Data management/consistency. These challenges arise from the recognition that edge computing forms a crucial layer between cloud systems and mobile or edge devices. Given that an application encompasses both computing and data, the distribution of computing and data across these layers and among edge servers emerges as a focal point in edge computing research. Task scheduling tackles the optimal allocation of computing resources, service migration involves system implementation for flexible scheduling, and data consistency becomes pivotal in handling distributed data.

This project propose a comprehensive architecture and explore solutions to these fundamental problems in edge computing systems. The system introduces detailed techniques in task scheduling, such as edge task queue management and inter-edge collaboration. Notably, a significant innovation of this project is the design and implementation of docker-based service migration in the edge computing environment. It also pioneers the exploration of data management, data consistency, and distributed consensus protocols for edge commuting. Additionally, the project takes into account emerging deep learning-based edge computing applications. The system supports deep learning by considering model distillation, communication reduction, privacy and security support, and Byzantine fault-tolerant algorithms in the edge computing environment.
